Dear Rhonda Ann Westphal:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616)204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159: Youth restraint; pregnant youth,
Section reduction, prevention, prohibited restraints, elimination of
Description restraints
(4) Only the least restrictive intervention necessary to prevent
immediate harm to the youth or others may be used and must
follow an individualized set of graduated interventions that avoid
the use of restraints.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
1

Allegation Youth was restrained before the intervention was needed.
Investigation On 2/3/23, I spoke to Complainant 1 via telephone. Complainant 1
did not add any other details to the alleged complaint.
I spoke to Administrator 1 via telephone on 2/3/23. Administrator 1
reported that Youth A was restrained, and it was a "clean
restraint". Administrator 1 reported that Youth A was restrained
after he had verbally threatened peers and staff. Administrator 1
reported that Youth A ran towards other youth in the group to
physically attack them and then was restrained.
I reviewed the video on 2/6/23. The video was for the incident date
on 1/30/23. The video reveals Youth A sitting down on a chair and
Staff 1 and Staff 2 are near him. They opened up Youth A's
bedroom door and were pointing for Youth A to go into his room
for a behavior management timeout (seclusion). Youth A refused
and stood up and walked from one end of the room to the other.
Three youth sitting at a table then got up and were removing
themselves from the area when Youth A ran towards them. Youth
A was then restrained.
All interviews were conducted face to face on 2/6/23 at the facility
with DHHS Worker 1 unless otherwise noted.
Youth A reported he was not following the rules of the facility and
a "Group Attention" (GA) was conducted. Youth A reported he
would not accept responsibility so; he was placed on a "group
restriction" for not following the rules of the facility. Group
restriction meant that he was to be sent away from the group and
quietly think about his actions. Youth A reported Youth B was
stating comments to him that were not appropriate and when
Youth A voiced his concerns then Staff 1 asked him to go into his
room for a BMT (Behavior Management Timeout). Youth A
reported he refused and then "postured" towards Youth B and
went towards Youth B and stated, "Let's get crackin" insinuating
he wanted to fight Youth B. Youth A reported that Staff 1 grabbed
his arm and restrained him.
Youth B and Youth C both reported that Youth A would not accept
responsibility for his behavior earlier and was on "group
restrictions". Both youth reported that Youth A came after them
and stated "let's get this crackin" insinuating Youth A wanted to
fight with Youth B. Both youth reported that Staff 1 grabbed Youth
A to restraint Youth A. Both youth reported they left the area per
procedure when a youth was getting restrained.
2

Staff 1 reported Youth A was upset with the other youth in the unit.
Staff 1 reported they called a GA and Youth A refused to be a part
of it. Staff 1 reported that they then placed Youth A on a "group
restriction" meaning he was not a part of the youth activities until
he accepted and changed behavior. In the meantime he had to sit
and not talk. Youth A was compliant with the group restriction but
then placed his sweater over his head. Staff 1 reported he
redirected Youth A and then Youth A got upset and was cussing.
Staff 1 reported he opened Youth A's bedroom door to give him a
BMT and Youth A refused to enter. Youth A then started cussing
and threatening the other youth in the unit, stating they were
threatening him. Youth A got up from his chair and stated, "let's
get this crackin" and went after the other youth on the other side of
the unit. Staff 1 then restrained him.
Analysis Video observation and interviews with Youth A, B, and C and Staff
1 all confirm that Youth A was verbally threatening the other youth
in the unit and did attempt to go after Youth B. Staff intervened to
provide safety of the youth. All reported the behavior management
process, group attention, group restriction, and BMT were all
offered to Youth A before a restraint was utilized.
Technical Assistance: It was clear in the video and in interviews
that Youth A was sitting quietly in his chair away from the unit.
Only when confronted about placing his head in his shirt did he
begin to escalate. A training may be warranted to discuss when
and where to "pick battles" concerning a youth's behavior. Another
area of Technical Assistance is to remove the targeted audience
quicker.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth, reduction,
Section prevention, prohibited restraints, elimination of restraints
Description (2) The following restraints are strictly prohibited: (e) Restraining
youth in a prone position or any restraint that restricts the youth’s
airway.
(5) In the event a restraint occurs, it must be performed in a
manner that is safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity
of the youth’s behavior, chronological and developmental age,
size, gender, physical condition, medical condition, psychiatric
condition, and personal history, including any history of trauma,
and must be done in a manner consistent with the youth’s
treatment plan.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
3

Allegation Youth was restrained and had a bruise (handprint) on his arm and
bruising on his knees from the restraint. Youth was initially
grabbed by the throat.
Investigation On 2/3/23, I spoke to Complainant 1 via telephone. Complainant 1
did not add any other details to the alleged complaint.
Complainant 1 did confirm she visually saw bruises on Youth A's
arm that looked like fingerprints and that Youth A had bruises on
his knees.
I reviewed the video of the restraint on 2/6/23. The incident took
place on 1/30/23 from 6:20:43pm-6:57:10pm. The following
observations are noted from the video:
The video shows from 6:40:40-6:40:53pm Youth A was in a prone
restraint. Youth A attempted to get up and then went down on his
side but then placed back into prone from 6:41:23-6:42:03 until
lifted up from prone by Staff 1 and Staff 2. It is to be noted that
Staff did not release their holds from Youth A when he was prone.
From 6:42:10-6:51:30, Youth A was restrained up against the wall
of the unit. Youth A was facing the wall while restrained up against
it.
All interviews were conducted face to face on 2/6/23 at the facility
with DHHS Worker 1 unless otherwise noted.
The facility uses the MACH restraint module. Supervisor 1, trainer
of MACH, reported that prone restraints and restraining an
individual up against the wall are not trained in the MACH module.
Supervisor 1 reported they are not providing any tools or direction
at this time to staff when a youth goes into prone position on
accident.
Staff 1 reported he did not think that Youth A was prone, but only
on his side. Staff 1 reported that he had Youth A's arm but was
also attempting to get his radio from Youth A. Youth A had gotten
a hold of his radio as they fell to the ground during the restraint.
Staff 1 reported they do not take kids to the ground for restraints
and that the main reason to restrain is to get the youth into their
room for seclusion. Staff 1 reported when they got Youth A up, he
continued to fight so they placed him up against the wall and
restrained him there until they were able to get him into the
bedroom. Staff 1 reported in MACH training, they are allowed to
restrain a youth against the wall. Staff 1 reported that Nurse 1 did
enter into the unit and stated they were placing too much pressure
on his back, so they released pressure.
4

Staff 2 reported that Staff 1 and Youth A fell to the ground during
the restraint. Staff 2 reported they were struggling on the ground,
and it took some time to get up from the ground. Staff 2 reported
he did not think that Youth A was prone, but only on his side. Staff
2 reported when they got him to his feet, they then restrained him
up against the wall. Staff 2 reported that Nurse 1 entered in the
unit and made a comment to make sure that Youth A could
breathe well.
Supervisor 2 reported that when she entered into the unit, they
were on the ground with Youth A trying to get him up from the
floor. Supervisor 2 reported that they got him up and restrained
him against the wall. Since Youth A would not deescalate, they
handcuffed him and took him into his room for seclusion.
Supervisor 2 reported she did not hear if Nurse 1 stated anything
during the restraint.
Staff 3 reported that when he entered the unit, he helped place
Youth A in a restraint up against the wall. Staff 3 reported they
placed handcuffs on Youth A and then walked him to his room for
seclusion. Staff 3 did not hear anything from Nurse 1.
Youth A reported he was restrained after he attempted to
"posture" against Youth B. Youth A reported he went towards
Youth B and stated, let's "get to crackin". Youth A reported Staff 1
grabbed him by his arm and pulled him back and then they fell to
the ground. Youth A reported that Staff 1 and Staff 2 were holding
him to the ground and one of the staff was holding his neck down.
Youth A reported he was laying on his chest. Youth A reported he
attempted to get up from the floor and Staff 1 and Staff 2 pushed
him back down. Youth A reported he was then let up and
"slammed" against the door. Youth A reported when Nurse 1
came in she told the staff to stop pressing on his back. Youth A
reported they then put handcuffs on him and he went into his room
for the rest of the night in a "BMT" (Behavior Management
Timeout). Youth A reported he had bruises on his arm and knees
because of the restraint.
I observed Youth A on 2/6/23 and I could not verify bruises.
I reviewed training files for Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 3, Staff 4, and
Staff 5. All staff had updated training in MACH.
Staff 2 did have discipline in his file for the following items:
5

2018: Failure to read and follow Behavior Management Plan and
Resident Medical Assessment and failure to exercise appropriate
supervision when youth escalated.
2021: Suspension for not using the approved restraint system
2022: Last Chance Agreement: repeatedly entering unit office and
using personal phone. Failure to complete security round and
falsifying documentation.
I reviewed the MACH restraint techniques via internet training.
I reviewed the Use of Force Policy which identifies MACH as the
restraint module in use.
Analysis Video observation and interview with Youth A confirm that Youth A
was in a prone position while being restrained. Although Staff 1
and Youth A fell to the ground, Staff 1 and Staff 2 did not release
their hold on Youth A. Both continued to hold him while they
struggled with Youth A. Youth A was also restrained up against a
wall, face first, for over nine minutes. The MACH training does not
teach this, verified by Supervisor 1, trainer for MACH. The
restraint was not completed in a manner that was safe or
appropriate, due to it being outside of the restraint module,
including prone position and restrained face first up against the
wall.
Technical Assistance:
To ensure the safety of youth involved in a restraint, any time a
restraint is initiated, and youth and staff fall to the floor, the
restraint should immediately be stopped. MACH restraints do not
allow for a floor restraint; therefore, there should not be a time that
staff are holding a youth when they are on the floor. While
reviewing the agency “Use of Force Policy” it noted, “If the
resident ends up in the prone position during a physical restraint,
handcuffs will be applied, and the resident brought to a sitting or
standing position.” This will need to be removed from their policy
as this is not an appropriate usage of mechanical restraints
outlined in the law or rules.
Conclusion REPEAT Violation Established
SIR 2022C0137007 INTAKE 12/9/21; CAP APPROVED 2/23/22
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4162 Seclusion within secure and nonsecure
Section facilities; seclusion plan; prohibitions; reduction and
Description elimination
(11) All seclusion will be prohibited effective November 1, 2022.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
6

Allegation The agency is using seclusion and is not permitted to do so in
accordance with the rules.
Investigation All interviews were conducted face to face with DHHS Worker 1 at
the facility on 2/6/23.
Administrator 1 reported Youth A was placed in seclusion.
I reviewed the Incident Report dated 1/30/23. The incident report
noted that Youth A was placed in "confinement" for behavior
management. Supervisor 2 was notified of the confinement.
According to video, Youth A was placed in his room at 6:53:55pm.
Video observation of the incident shows Youth A being initially
asked to go into his room before he was restrained, and Youth A
refused. After the restraint, Youth A was handcuffed and walked to
his room for seclusion.
Supervisor 1 reported youth always go into their room for
seclusion after they are restrained.
Youth A reported that youth receive BMT's for behaviors such as
"cussing" at staff or being defiant. Youth A reported there are two
type of BMT's. The first type is the youth will go into their room
and sit on the mattress. The time is anywhere between 1-1.5
hours. The door will not be locked but they are not allowed to get
up or leave the room. The second type is called a "reentry." A
reentry occurs after a restraint. Their mattress is removed from
their room, and they have to sit on the concrete slab. The door is
shut and locked. Youth A was restrained on 1/30/23 and reported
that he was placed in a BMT after the restraint and did not come
out the rest of the night.
Youth C reported there is a process for entering into a BMT. First
a peer in the group redirects the youth not following the rules, then
a different peer redirects him if he doesn't listen. If this doesn't
work, then they get into a circle as a group and process the
behavior. If the youth still does not accept responsibility, then the
youth receive a group restriction which means they are not
involved in whatever activity the group is doing and they are
unable to talk. Youth C reported they are not allowed out of their
room and have to sit down on their bed. Youth C reported they are
not allowed to read or lay down or this will extend their time. Youth
C reported they could be in the room for 15 minutes up to one
hour depending on how the youth acts in the room. Youth C
reported that Youth A went into a BMT after his restraint.
7

Youth B reported the youth at the facility do receive BMT's if they
are not following the program. Youth B reported they can go
willingly to their room over minor issues, but if they are threatening
or aggressive, they will be restrained and placed in the room for a
BMT. Both BMT's the youth are not allowed to leave the room.
Youth C reported you must have four 15-minute checks of
compliance before you can come out of the room.
Staff 1 reported Youth A was placed in BMT after his restraint.
Staff 1 reported youth do enter into BMT as a consequence for
acting out, cussing, throwing things, and threatening behavior.
Staff 1 reported that the door only gets locked if they are
threatening or restrained. Staff 1 reported there is two 15-minute
checks before the youth can come out of the BMT. Staff 1
reported that after restraints youth are to go into seclusion and
Staff 1 reported he has never been told not to seclude youth. Staff
1 reported BMT's usually occur daily.
Staff 2 reported they do place youth in seclusion. Staff 2 reported
this is a relatively normal consequence. Staff 2 reported they can
come out of their room if they have had two 15-minute checks of
compliance.
Supervisor 2 reported that BMT's are rarely used. Supervisor 2
reported that once youth have deescalated, they are to come out
of their room.
Staff 3 reported Youth A was placed in seclusion after the restraint
and stayed in his room until the next day.
Both Staff 4 and Staff 5 reported BMT's are used but not often.
All staff and Supervisor 1 and Supervisor 2 reported they were not
aware they could not use seclusion.
Analysis New Child Caring Licensing Rules went into effect on May 31,
2022. A Child Caring Institution Letter was sent out to all CCI's.
The new rules explicitly state that on November 1, 2022, all
seclusion will be prohibited. The agency, after receiving the new
rules, had to provide policy updates to their consultant. The
agency was informed of the new rules and did not abide by them.
Staff and supervisors report they are unaware of the new rule and
was never provided direction to stop using seclusion.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
8

The agency does have written procedures, for completing a health
status screening, but they are not sufficient. The agency's current
policy states that the supervisor is to notify the medical
department and the medical department will evaluate the youth.
The procedure for what an evaluation consists of is not outlined.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
